back: The product of matrices $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{B}$ is written \(\mathbf{A} \mathbf{B}\) and is defined if the inner dimensions of these matrices agree; that is, if \(\mathbf{A}\) is a \(k \times \ell\) matrix and \(\mathbf{B}\) is an \(\ell \times m\) matrix. In that case, the output is a \(k \times m\) matrix \(\mathbf{C} = \mathbf{A} \mathbf{B}\), where the \(k,m\mbox{th}\) entry of \(\mathbf{C}\) is given by \(c_{k,m} = \mathbf{a}_{k*} \cdot \mathbf{b}_m\) (the dot product of the \(k\)th row of \(\mathbf{A}\) with the \(m\)th column of \(\mathbf{B}\) ).
A (real) square matrix whose columns are a set of orthonormal vectors.

For a matrix \(\mathbf{A}\), the Gram matrix is the matrix whose \(i,j\)th entry is the dot product of columns \(i\) and \(j\) of \(\mathbf{A}\). The Gram matrix can be calculated as \(\mathbf{A}^\mbox{T} \mathbf{A}\).
A matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is symmetric if the \(i,j\mbox{th}\) element is equal to the \(j,i\mbox{th}\) element for any valid \(i\) and \(j\). Equivalently, \(\mathbf{M}^\mbox{T} = \mathbf{M}\).
